docs.lead_paragraph: The giant insurer outraged customers by proposing a 40 percent rise in some premiums a few years ago. Nowadays, it has emerged as the biggest participant in state marketplaces.

headline.main: WellPoint, a Onetime Critic of Health Law, May Yet Profit
headline.print_headline: Ex-Critic of Health Law May Yet Profit

docs.abstract: Private health insurer WellPoint, former critic of new health care law, has emerged as biggest participant in newly created state marketplaces, capturing leading share of the market in at least half-dozen states; story of how company went from health care opponent to beneficiary provides look at how industry is changing, and potentially thriving, under Affordable Care Act.
docs.snippet: The giant insurer outraged customers by proposing a 40 percent rise in some premiums a few years ago. Nowadays, it has emerged as the biggest participant in state marketplaces.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: A judge in Idaho ruled against a hospital deal, saying that patient costs would have risen, but that outcomes would have been improved.

headline.main: Health Law Goals Face Antitrust Hurdles
headline.print_headline: Health Law Goals Face Antitrust Hurdles

docs.abstract: Eduardo Porter Economic Scene column notes that Idaho district judge has ruled against merger between St Luke's Health System and Saltzer Medical Group, saying that patient costs would have risen; observes that decision underlines potentially important conflict between nation's anti-monopoly laws and Affordable Care Act, which has encouraged creation of big, broad accountable care organizations.
docs.snippet: A judge in Idaho ruled against a hospital deal, saying that patient costs would have risen, but that outcomes would have been improved.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: With the expansion of insurance coverage, more workers will choose not to work and others will choose to work fewer hours than they might have otherwise, according to the Congressional Budget Office.

headline.main: Health Care Law Projected to Cut the Labor Force
headline.print_headline: Health Care Law Projected to Cut the Labor Force

docs.abstract: Congressional Budget Office analysis predicts that the Affordable Care Act will shrink the private-sector work force by the equivalent of more than two million full-time positions, as more people turn down jobs they would have taken just to obtain employer-provided insurance; Republicans seize on worse-than-expected estimate as evidence that the law is a job killer, putting Obama administration and Democrats on the defensive.
docs.snippet: With the expansion of insurance coverage, more workers will choose not to work and others will choose to work fewer hours than they might have otherwise, according to the Congressional Budget Office.

docs.lead_paragraph: President Barack Obama's healthcare law will reduce the American workforce by the equivalent of 2 million full-time workers in 2017, the Congressional Budget Office said on Tuesday, prompting Republicans to paint the law as bad medicine for the U.S. economy.

docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. health officials have investigated whether some of the software used in computers at the heart of President Barack Obama's healthcare reform was written in Belarus, but have found no evidence of that being the case, a White House official said on Tuesday.

docs.lead_paragraph: Republicans said on Tuesday they hoped to attach deficit-reduction measures to legislation raising the U.S. debt limit, but a new government report that forecast a more favorable budget outlook had the potential to undercut their efforts.
